questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must configure static NAT on R1 to allow users HTTP access to the web server on TCP port 80. The web server must be reachable through ISP 1 and ISP 2. Which command set should be applied to R1 to fulfill these requirements?

discussion.content: The NAT extendable parameter can be used if you want to translate a private IP address to more than one public IP address.

comments.content: And if you enter "no-alias", the NAT-router won't answer for ARP replies for that IP.

discussion.content:
A.
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.200.225 80 extendable
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.201.1 80 extendable

B.
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.200.225 80
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.201.1 80

C.
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.200.225 80 no-alias
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.201.1 80 no-alias

D.
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 80 209.165.200.225 80
ip nat inside source static tcp 10.1.1.100 8080 209.165.201.1 8080

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
https://networklessons.com/uncategorized/nat-extendable-on-cisco-ios
Provided answer is correct.

Port Flags State Priority Key Key Number State

Dec 21 21:51:58.051: %LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface Port-channel2, changed state to up
Dec 21 21:51:59.055: %LINEPROTO-5-UPDOWN: Line protocol on Interface Port-channel2, changed state to up

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Hot-Standby (hot-sby): It´s already configured and synchronized with the LACP group but remains in standby mode because the LACP group has reached its maximum number of active ports.
If one of the active ports goes down, the hot-standby port can quickly transition to an active state, minimizing downtime and ensuring continued data flow.

Since the interface Gi0/0 is in hot-sby mode, we need to set LACP Max-Bundle to 2, this increases the number of active ports allowed in the port channel to 2.

D is incorrect because Gi0/0 is already in hot-standby due to max-bundle constraints, changing it to active mode won't resolve the underlying limit on the number of active ports.
B seems to be correct, neds to be tested in lab

Selected Answer: B
This is the explanation of why B is Correct:
From Cisco:
The value specified in the max-bundle-number argument determines the number of active links that are bundled in the port channel. The remaining links are in hot-standby mode.

In the output we see 1 port as standby, therefore we must issue max-bundle 2 so both interfaces are active.
LACP (Link Aggregation Control Protocol) open (IEEE) standard. Supports more than 8links in a channel, but only 8 can be in operation and rest as standby

comments.content: D is for a static port-channel "on". we are using Active/Passive with is LACP.

discussion.content: B has nothing to do with this, answer is D

Selected Answer: B
The answer B is correct.
LACP hot-standby port:
"When enabled, LACP tries to configure the maximum number of LACP-compatible ports in a channel, up to a maximum of 16 ports. "
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/blades/3020/software/release/12-2_50_se/configuration/guide/scg/swethchl.pdf

Selected Answer: B
"B" it´s correct.

choices.D: logging discriminator Disc1 severity includes 7 facility includes fac7

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer is enabling logging to a local buffer, to the terminal, and to a syslog server for all debugging level logs filtered by facility code 7. Which command is needed to complete this configuration snippet?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The “logging discriminator Disc1 severity includes 7 facility includes fac7” command enables the logging discriminator named Disc1 to filter messages with a severity level of 7 (debugging level) and facility code 7.

comments.content: fac7 is a field within a facility message, if message contains fac7 it will be included

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
logging discriminator discr-name [[facility ] [mnemonics ] [msg-body ] {drops string | includes string }] [severity {drops sev-num | includes sev-num }] [rate-limit msglimit ]

Example: 

Device(config)# logging discriminator pacfltr1 facility includes facl357


See https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/esm/configuration/xe-16-12/esm-xe-16-12-book/reliable-del-filter.html

D.
Priority value of the message; a combination of the facility value and the severity value of the message. Priority value = (facility value* 8) + severity value. 
....

The facility code valid options are:

LOCAL0 (Code = 16)
LOCAL1 (Code = 17)
LOCAL2 (Code = 18)
LOCAL3 (Code = 19)
LOCAL4 (Code = 20)
LOCAL5 (Code = 21)
LOCAL6 (Code = 22; default)
LOCAL7 (Code = 23)
Local7 is a default

Selected Answer: D
I think D is correct, here is a sample from Cisco for facility code 357:
(config)# logging discriminator pacfltr1 facility includes facl357

Selected Answer: B
"fac7" is not a regular expression for facility 7. Plus, facility 7 is default so you don't need to specify it in discriminator. In my humble opinion, answer should be B.

comments.content: I may be wrong though, since it's specifically saying "facility code", which for Cisco's case, default is code 23 (local7). Answer D is still sensible.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Going with D

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the snippets onto the blanks within the code to construct a script that adds a prefix list to a route map and sets the local preference. Not all options are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The answer is wrong.

"running": null
Name:100
Permit
Match

I would put the following:

1. “running”: null <<<<target running config
2. “name”:”100″, <<<<< prefix list name "100"
3. “seq_no”: <<<<<<< there is no permit command within a route map. this is the only logical selection here.
4. “match”: again within a route map we can either set, or match.

comments.content: link did not work. Please re-paste.

discussion.content:
"running": null
Name:100
Permit
Match

This is a very tricky question. For any production route-map I have ever created and as per Cisco's documentation, you of course can and do specify a permit | deny, without this all traffic that is matched is implicitly denied in the route-map and where it is applied, why some people are stating permit | deny is not used in a route-map is very strange misinformation, it is a key component in the traffic engineering process. 
However in rare cases you can create a route-map without a permit or deny statement, specifying a sequence number only which is used to update an existing route-map entry. 
It seems too odd that Cisco would ask you to update an existing route-map when no other question I've come across asks for even basic route-map configuration. Surely we create the entry using a standard 'permit' here.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/asa/asa84/configuration/guide/asa_84_cli_config/route_maps.pdf

checked with real RPC model:
the correct order :

running
name
seq_no
match

given answer is incorrect

"running": null
"name":"100",
"permit":
"match":

https://techhub.hpe.com/eginfolib/networking/docs/switches/K-KA-KB/16-02/5200-1671_K_MRG/content/ch11s06.html#:~:text=If%20the%20route%2Dmap%20has%20more%20than%20one%20sequence%2C%20the%20sequence%20number%20is%20required%3A%20route%2Dmap%20name%20permit%20%7C%20deny%20seq%20seq%2Dnum%20.

...........

discussion.content:
i think it's like this
running
name
Seq
match

"running": null
Name:100
Permit

NETCONF <edit-config> Request: CLI Format
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<rpc message-id="101" xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:netconf:base:1.0"> 
 <edit-config>
 <target>
 <running/>
 </target>
 <config>
Is it a Resconf sample?

- "running": null
- "name":"100"
- "permit"
- "match"
TIP: runapem

1 - running
2 - name
3 - seq (this is a route-map)
4 - match the acl/prefix for the route-map.

Answer:
1. “running”: null
2. “name”:”100″,
3. “seq_no”:
4. “match”:

Suggested answer is wrong. If I understand correctly, correct should be:

* "running": null
* "name":"100"
* "permit"
* "match"

The order in the route-map is a bit odd, the "match" part comes first and after that comes the "set" part... 
But, in the running-config (that is the target) in IOS this would be:

* ip prefix-list 100 seq 10 permit 0.0.0.0/0 <- name of prefix-list is "100"
* route-map Routes permit 10 <- "permit" 10
* match ip address prefix-list 100 <- "match" the prefix-list "100"
* set local-preference 200
